posts.content: Let’s play a game. Take a look at the two companies and tell me which is better: [Thread1]
Company A is a content platform founded in 1997. Last year, it did $30 billion in revenue, +18% YoY, with 225 million users, spending $19 billion on content in 2021. [Thread1]
Company B, also a content platform, founded in 2005, did $30 billion in revenue last year, +46% YoY, with 2.6 billion users, without spending on content—users produce it. [Thread1]
Which business model is better? You probably chose Company B. Why? Because it crowdsources content instead of spending $19 billion. [Thread1]
Company B is YouTube and Company A is Netflix. Both had $30 billion in revenue last year, but with very different business models. [Thread1]

Netflix spends billions on content, YouTube taps the world's creativity. Netflix focuses on expensive productions like _Stranger Things_ and _Squid Game_, while YouTube thrives on user-generated content. [Thread1]
Netflix vs. YouTube: Let's delve into the numbers. Netflix has 225 million paying subscribers. YouTube has 2.6 billion monthly active users. [Thread2]

ARPU (Average Revenue Per User) differs greatly: YouTube = $11.50; Netflix = $38.70. Despite differences, the basic principle stands: Netflix pours billions into content, YouTube crowdsources. [Thread2]
Chris Anderson’s long tail concept (WIRED, 2004) predicted such platforms. He emphasized niche markets over “megahits.” [Thread2]
Barry Diller’s 2005 quote (“There is not that much talent in the world”) didn’t age well. YouTube, founded the same year, showed there was a lot of talent globally. [Thread2]

Long-tail markets have revolutionized tech companies. Google, Facebook, eBay & many startups exploit niche markets. Examples: Etsy (artisanal products), GOAT (sneakers), Discord (community servers). [Thread3]
Amazon is a prime long-tail example. Most book sales come from outside its top 130,000 titles. Netflix, Spotify, and others built on expanding content/music selection. [Thread3]
For long-tail success, efficient inventory management is crucial. Example: Amazon ensures niche products are in stock, maintaining customer satisfaction. [Thread3]
Long-tail platforms are more egalitarian. They allow tastes to be defined by customer preferences rather than executives. Example: K-pop’s rise without radio popularity. [Thread4]
Recommendations are pivotal in long-tail success. Amazon, Netflix, YouTube, and Spotify utilize these to drive content discovery and commerce. [Thread4]
Long-tail success depends on _recommendations_ shaping user preferences. Companies tailor content (like TikTok’s For You Page) to user tastes. [Thread4]
TikTok’s For You Page revolutionizes content discovery by algorithmic recommendations. TikTok’s creativity is unmatched due to remix culture and built-in tools. [Thread5]
AI tools like Midjourney and DALL-E make content creation easier, extending the long tail even further. The future focuses more on diverse creators. [Thread5]
Commerce also benefits from the long tail. Shopify, with 1M storefronts, exemplifies this, supporting many small merchants rather than a few large ones. [Thread5]
New business models emerge, like Openstore, which acquires Shopify merchants, optimizing and growing their brands. Similar models thrive in Amazon roll-ups. [Thread5]
Startups like Pietra enable even small creators to launch product lines. Faire connects brands and retailers efficiently, aiding local shops. [Thread6]
Data-driven approaches: Faire helps retailers discover successful products from similar shops, optimizing selections. [Thread6]
Long-tail businesses often outperform those focusing only on major hits. TikTok, Shopify, and Faire highlight this trend. [Thread6]
Successful internet businesses create more jobs than they directly employ. Example: Shopify supports millions of jobs through its platform, far exceeding its 10,000 employees. [Thread6]
“Off-balance sheet operating leverage”: enabling entire ecosystems to form on a platform. Companies leveraging this concept will likely thrive. [Thread6]
Two decades later, Anderson’s long tail framework still guides how we evaluate tech businesses. The long tail continues to surprise in its extension and vibrancy. [Thread6]
